choices.text: Oxygen dissolved in the tear film

questions.text: From which sources does the cornea receive its nourishment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The cornea is avascular and receives nourishment by diffusion from multiple sources:
  • Aqueous humour (posterior source) provides glucose and nutrients. (Option A)
  • Tear film (anterior source) supplies oxygen and removes waste. (Option C)
  • Limbal capillaries provide additional metabolic support, especially for the peripheral cornea and during wound healing. (Option B)

Related Important Points:

  • The epithelium receives oxygen from the tear film.
  • The endothelium and posterior stroma depend on aqueous for glucose and other nutrients.
  • The limbus houses stem cells and blood vessels, which aid peripheral corneal support.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a metabolically active layer of the cornea?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bowman's layer is an acellular condensation of collagen in the anterior stroma, not a metabolically active layer.
  • It serves as a barrier but has no role in metabolism as it contains no viable cells.
  • The epithelium, stroma (keratocytes), and endothelium are all metabolically active and perform vital roles in corneal maintenance. (Option A, C, D ruled out )
  • The endothelium is particularly active, maintaining corneal deturgescence by pumping excess fluid out of the stroma.
  • Nutrient supply:
    • Oxygen is mostly derived from the tear film and partly from the limbal capillaries.
    • Glucose is primarily sourced from the aqueous humour (90%) and the limbus (10%).

Related Important Points:

  • Bowman's layer does not regenerate if damaged.
  • Keratocytes in the stroma play a crucial role in maintaining and repairing collagen.
  • Endothelial cells do not regenerate but enlarge to maintain function.

choices.text: Zygomatic division of the Facial Nerve

questions.text: The nerve supply of the cornea is derived from which cranial nerve division?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The cornea is innervated by branches of the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve, primarily the long ciliary nerves, which are branches of the nasociliary nerve.

  • These long ciliary nerves travel through the peri choroidal space and pierce the sclera just posterior to the limbus, forming an annular plexus.
  • From this plexus, branches extend radially into the corneal stroma, then pass anteriorly to form:
    • The subepithelial plexus in the anterior stroma
    • Further fine branches penetrate Bowman's membrane to form an intraepithelial nerve plexus.
  • These axons lose both myelin and Schwann cell sheaths, becoming naked, free nerve endings highly responsive to pain and temperature.
  • Despite the lack of specialised nerve endings or sensory corpuscles, the cornea is one of the most densely innervated structures in the body, making it extremely sensitive to even minor stimuli.

Related Important Points:

  • Maxillary (V2) and Mandibular (V3) divisions of the trigeminal nerve supply other facial regions, not the cornea.
  • The facial nerve is motor, and its zygomatic branch innervates orbicularis oculi, not corneal structures.
  • Damage to long ciliary nerve fibres may reduce corneal reflex or sensation.

Explanation of Other Options:

The maxillary division of the Trigeminal Nerve(Option B): Supplies the midface, not the cornea.

Mandibular division of Trigeminal Nerve(Option C): Innervates the lower face and jaw.

Zygomatic division of Facial Nerve(Option D): The Facial nerve is primarily motor; the zygomatic branch supplies orbicularis oculi, not the cornea.

Key Takeaway:

  • The cornea's dense sensory innervation comes from the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve, specifically via long ciliary nerves.

questions.text: What is the refractive index of the cornea?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The cornea is the primary refractive element of the eye, contributing about two-thirds of the eye's total refractive power (~43 diopters).

  • Its refractive index is approximately 1.376, which, combined with the significant difference from air (1.00), creates the strongest refractive surface in the visual pathway.
  • The anterior corneal surface, due to its curvature and refractive index, is responsible for the majority of this effect.

Related Important Points:

  • The lens has a higher index but lower curvature contribution than the cornea.
  • Small changes in corneal hydration or curvature can significantly affect visual acuity.

Key Takeaway:

The cornea, with a refractive index of 1.376, is the eye's most powerful refractive surface, particularly at the cornea-air interface.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is responsible for maintaining the hydration and transparency of the cornea?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Endothelial cells of the cornea are primarily responsible for maintaining corneal hydration and transparency.

  • These cells possess Na+/K+ ATPase pumps, which maintain the cornea in a relatively dehydrated state, essential for transparency.
  • Loss of endothelial function leads to corneal oedema and light scatter, impairing vision.
  • Endothelial cells do not regenerate; they decrease with age.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • Factors contributing to corneal transparency:
    • Regular arrangement of collagen lamellae (Maurice theory)
    • Peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae (Goldmann theory)
    • Avascularity of the cornea
    • A balance between IOP and corneal swelling pressure
  • Layers of the cornea (anterior to posterior):
    • Epithelium
    • Bowman's membrane
    • Stroma (substantia propria)
    • Dua's layer
    • Descemet's membrane
    • Endothelium

Explanation of Other Options:

Descemet's membrane (Option A): Serves as a basement membrane for the endothelium; not directly involved in dehydration.

Stroma (Option C): Comprises 90% of corneal thickness but plays a passive role in hydration; transparency relies on lamellar arrangement.

Corneal epithelium (Option D): Acts as a barrier but does not regulate stromal hydration actively.

Key Takeaway:

Corneal endothelium maintains dehydration and transparency through active Na+/K+ ATPase transport.

questions.text: Where are the corneal stem cells situated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Corneal epithelial regeneration depends on limbal stem cells located in the palisades of Vogt at the corneoscleral junction.

  • These stem cells are mitotically active and give rise to basal epithelial cells of the cornea.
  • Located at the limbus, the palisades of Vogt are radially oriented fibrovascular ridges that increase the surface area for stem cell niches.
  • Central corneal epithelium has minimal mitotic activity and relies on peripheral migration for regeneration.
  • In superficial injuries, rapid epithelial repair occurs predominantly via these limbal stem cells.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • Corneal epithelium is a non-keratinised stratified squamous layer capable of rapid regeneration.
  • Limbal stem cells maintain epithelial homeostasis and are essential in wound healing.
  • Damage or deficiency of limbal stem cells results in impaired corneal healing and conjunctivalization.

Explanation of Other Options:

Bowman's Layer (Option A): Acellular layer beneath the epithelium; does not contain stem cells.

Descemet's Layer (Option B): Basement membrane of the endothelium; not involved in epithelial regeneration.

Endothelium (Option C): Maintains corneal dehydration and clarity; no regenerative stem cells present.

Key Takeaway:

Limbal stem cells in the palisades of Vogt are essential for corneal epithelial regeneration.

choices.text: Epithelium defect staining with Sodium fluorescein
Epithelium defect staining with Bengal rose

questions.text: Identify the procedure demonstrated in the picture.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sodium fluorescein is a water-soluble dye that stains areas of absent epithelium, making epithelial defects visible under cobalt blue filtered light.

  • The dye absorbs blue light (peak ~490 nm) and emits yellow-green fluorescence (~530 nm).
  • A cobalt blue filter from the slit lamp or camera is used to excite fluorescein molecules.
  • It does not stain healthy epithelium but pools in areas where the epithelial barrier is disrupted.
  • Such staining is commonly used in evaluating corneal abrasions, erosions, ulcers, and during applanation tonometry for IOP measurement.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • Epithelial defects heal by migration and proliferation of surrounding epithelial cells within 24-48 hours.
  • Staining pattern helps in distinguishing between abrasions (superficial loss) and ulcers (with stromal involvement).
  • Fluorescein angiography uses the same dye but for retinal vascular evaluation, not the corneal surface.

Explanation of other options:

Epithelium defect staining with Bengal rose (Option A): Bengal rose stains dead and devitalized cells, not used for acute epithelial defects.

IOP measurement with Sodium fluorescein (Option C): While fluorescein is used in applanation tonometry, the image shows corneal surface staining, not IOP measurement.

None of the above (Option D): Incorrect, as the procedure shown matches epithelial defect staining.

Key Takeaway:

Sodium fluorescein stains corneal epithelial defects, appearing green under cobalt blue light, and is key for diagnosing corneal abrasions or erosions.

questions.text: How long does it typically take for a superficial corneal epithelial defect to heal in the absence of infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Superficial corneal epithelial defects, such as abrasions or erosions, usually heal rapidly due to the high regenerative capacity of the corneal epithelium.

  • Healing occurs by migration and proliferation of basal epithelial cells from the surrounding intact epithelium.
  • These cells slide over the defect and form new layers within 12-24 hours, provided there is no infection or inflammation.
  • Sodium fluorescein dye is commonly used to highlight such defects under cobalt blue light.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • Epithelial defect: Loss of superficial corneal epithelial cells; typically heals quickly.
  • Abrasion vs. Ulcer: Abrasion = superficial; Ulcer = involves stroma and takes longer to heal.
  • Fluorescein staining: Helps in early detection and assessment of the size and depth of the epithelial defect.

Key Takeaway:

  • Superficial epithelial defects of the cornea typically heal within 12-24 hours by epithelial cell migration.

questions.text: What is the standard concentration of Sodium fluorescein used for epithelium staining?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sodium fluorescein is routinely used at a concentration of 1% for the clinical evaluation of corneal epithelial defects.

  • It is a water-soluble orange dye that highlights areas of epithelial loss when viewed under cobalt blue filtered light.
  • Only denuded epithelium stains green, as intact epithelium resists dye penetration.
  • This technique is especially useful in detecting corneal abrasions, erosions, and ulcers, as well as in tonometry

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • Fluorescein dye mechanism: Excited by blue light (around 490 nm), emits green-yellow fluorescence (around 530 nm).
  • Uses: Epithelium defect detection, tear film break-up time (TBUT), contact lens fitting, applanation tonometry.
  • Common clinical use: Staining is done using impregnated paper strips dipped in saline or a pre-packaged 1% solution.

Key Takeaway:

  • The standard concentration of sodium fluorescein for epithelial staining is 1%, viewed under cobalt blue light.

questions.text: What does Pachymetry measure in ophthalmic evaluation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pachymetry is the measurement of central corneal thickness (CCT) and is essential in diagnosing and managing various corneal and glaucomatous conditions.

  • Normal CCT = 540 ± 30 microns.
  • It can be measured by:
    • Ultrasound pachymeter (most commonly used)
    • Orbscan or Pentacam (slit scanning topography systems)
    • An optical pachymeter attached to a slit lamp
  • CCT affects Goldmann applanation tonometry (GAT) readings:
    • Thin cornea → underestimated IOP
    • Thick cornea → overestimated IOP
  • CCT measurement is crucial in ocular hypertension and normal-tension glaucoma for risk stratification.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • Tonometry is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP).
  • Schirmer's test assesses tear film secretion.
  • Keratometry evaluates corneal curvature.
  • CCT is also a practical marker of endothelial function.

Explanation of other options:

Measurement of IOP (Option A): Done using tonometry, not pachymetry.

Measurement of tear film secretion (Option B): Assessed via Schirmer's test.

Measurement of corneal curvature (Option D): Done using keratometry or corneal topography.

Key Takeaway:

  • Pachymetry is used to measure corneal thickness, an essential parameter in glaucoma evaluation and corneal health.

questions.text: For her final year thesis, an ophthalmology resident is studying endothelial cell loss due to phacoemulsification surgery. The image is taken during the pre-operative evaluation of one of the cataract patients. What does this specular microscopy image show?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image is a specular microscopy view showing corneal endothelial cells with variation in size (polymegathism) and variation in shape (pleomorphism), indicating endothelial dysfunction.

  • A healthy endothelium shows uniform hexagonal
  • Endothelial cells are non-dividing, terminally differentiated cells. When some die, the remaining ones stretch to maintain the endothelial barrier.
  • This stretching leads to changes in cell size (polymegathism) and shape (pleomorphism).
  • These changes are commonly assessed pre-operatively in cataract or refractive surgeries to evaluate the risk of corneal decompensation.

Related Important Points:

  • Polymegathism = variation in cell size
  • Pleomorphism = variation in cell shape
  • Seen in ageing, Fuchs endothelial dystrophy, trauma, and post-surgical states
  • Specular microscopy is a non-invasive method to evaluate endothelial health
  • Corneal guttata appear as dark excrescences on Descemet's membrane-;not seen in this image

Explanation of other options:

Normal endothelium (Option A): Shows uniform hexagonal cells with no significant variation in size or shape.

Polymegathism only (Option B): Variation only in size, not shape and does not explain full image findings.

Corneal guttata (Option D): Shows dark drop-like lesions; absent here.

Key Takeaway:

  • Polymegathism and pleomorphism on specular microscopy are early markers of endothelial dysfunction.

questions.text: Identify the type of corneal opacity depicted in the image below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a dense, white, totally opaque corneal scar-this is characteristic of a leucomatous corneal opacity.

  • Leucomatous opacity is intensely white and dense, obscuring the view of the iris and pupil completely.
  • These scars usually follow deep or perforated corneal ulcers or severe keratitis.
  • Unlike nebular or macular opacities, no iris or pupillary details are visible.

questions.text: Identify the lesions demonstrated in the image below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows comma-shaped lesions attached to the cornea at one end, this is characteristic of filamentary keratitis.

  • Filamentary keratopathy involves strands of degenerated epithelial cells and mucus attached at one end to the cornea and free at the other end.
  • Filaments move with blinking and can cause significant foreign body sensation, redness, and photophobia.
  • These filaments stain with rose Bengal and, to a lesser extent, with fluorescein.
  • It is commonly associated with dry eye (keratoconjunctivitis sicca), contact lens overuse, corneal epithelial instability, bullous keratopathy, and neurotrophic keratopathy.

Related Important Points:

Explanation of other options:

Epithelial defect (Option A): Appears as a break or loss in the corneal epithelium, not filamentary in nature.

Corneal ulcer (Option B): Localised excavation of cornea with infiltrates and epithelial loss, filaments are not a typical feature.

Globe perforation (Option D): Full-thickness ocular injury, presents with hypotony, not filamentary strands.

Key Takeaway:

Filamentary keratitis presents with comma-shaped mucous-epithelial strands adherent to the cornea, commonly seen in dry eye and ocular surface disease.

questions.text: Which of the following corneal conditions is not likely to present with the following feature?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Arcus senilis is a peripheral corneal stromal opacity caused by lipid deposition. It is not associated with any changes in corneal nerve prominence.

  • Prominent corneal nerves are a diagnostic clue in several conditions, like:
    • Keratoconus
    • Acanthamoeba keratitis
    • Fuchs endothelial dystrophy
    • Congenital glaucoma
    • Neurofibromatosis
    • MEN syndrome type II b
  • In contrast, arcus senilis is a common age-related corneal degeneration that presents as a bilateral white perilimbal ring with no nerve involvement.

Explanation of other options:

Acanthamoeba keratitis (Option A): Causes radial perineural infiltrates and thickened nerves early in the disease.

Keratoconus (Option C): Shows early prominence of corneal nerves, especially in the inferotemporal quadrant.

Fuchs's endothelial dystrophy (Option D): May show nerve prominence due to chronic stress on the corneal endothelium.

Key Takeaway:

  • Arcus senilis involves lipid deposition in the corneal periphery and does not affect corneal nerves.

questions.text: Which of the following are features of corneal dystrophic conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Corneal dystrophies are a group of non-inflammatory, bilateral, and hereditary disorders that lead to progressive opacification of specific layers of the cornea.

  • They are usually bilateral and symmetrical, slowly progressive, and often categorised by the primary layer affected: epithelium, Bowman's layer, stroma, or endothelium.
  • Most do not cause neovascularisation of the cornea and remain avascular. (Option B ruled out)
  • Many dystrophies have known genetic mutations, with several classified based on molecular findings.

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway:

  • Corneal dystrophies are bilateral, hereditary, non-vascular, and non-inflammatory disorders affecting specific corneal layers.

choices.text: Involve the epithelium and corneal stroma

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding epithelial corneal dystrophies is/are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All the listed statements are incorrect regarding epithelial corneal dystrophies.

  • Epithelial corneal dystrophies primarily involve the epithelium and basement membrane, not the stroma. (Option A ruled out)
  • They are typically seen in adults, not in children. (Option B ruled out)
  • Symptoms include recurrent corneal erosions, foreign body sensation, pain, photophobia, and often blurring of vision, so visual disturbances are present. (Option C ruled out)

Examples include:

  • Epithelial basement membrane dystrophy (EBMD),k.a. Map-Dot-Fingerprint dystrophy
  • Meesmann dystrophy (may begin in early life, but symptoms often manifest later)

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway:

  • Epithelial corneal dystrophies typically involve the epithelium and basement membrane, present in adults, and are associated with visual symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an epithelial/sub-epithelial corneal dystrophy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fuchs's corneal dystrophy is a posterior corneal dystrophy, specifically affecting the Descemet membrane and endothelium, not the epithelial or subepithelial layers.

  • Epithelial and subepithelial corneal dystrophies involve the anterior corneal layers and include:
    • Map-dot-fingerprint dystrophy (also called epithelial basement membrane dystrophy) (Option A ruled out)
    • Cogan microcystic dystrophy (Option B ruled out)
    • Meesmann epithelial dystrophy (Option D ruled out)
    • Gelatinous drop-like dystrophy, Lisch dystrophy, etc.
  • Fuchs dystrophy, by contrast, causes corneal oedema, guttata, and endothelial dysfunction, especially in elderly individuals.

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway:

  • Fuchs's dystrophy is an endothelial corneal dystrophy, not part of the epithelial/subepithelial group.

questions.text: Which of the following is/ are the inheritance pattern of Bowman corneal dystrophy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bowman layer corneal dystrophies, such as Reis-Bücklers dystrophy and Thiel-Behnke dystrophy, are autosomal dominant in inheritance.

  • These dystrophies involve replacement or disruption of the Bowman layer by abnormal connective tissue or curly fibres.
  • Symptoms begin in childhood with recurrent corneal erosions, and visual impairment progresses as dense subepithelial opacities increase with age.
  • Both conditions are associated with mutations in the TGFB1 gene.

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway:

  • Bowman layer corneal dystrophies, such as Reis-Bücklers and Thiel-Behnke follow an autosomal dominant

questions.text: Which of the following is /are feature of Bowman's corneal dystrophy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bowman layer corneal dystrophies, such as Reis-Bücklers dystrophy and Thiel-Behnke dystrophy, are characterised by:

  • Autosomal dominant inheritance, not recessive (Option A ruled out)
  • Onset in childhood, not at birth (Option B ruled out)
  • Recurrent corneal erosions as a primary symptom
  • Progressive visual impairment due to increasing corneal opacities with age (Option D ruled out)

These dystrophies involve disruption or replacement of the Bowman layer by abnormal connective tissue or "curly fibres," depending on the subtype.

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway:

  • Recurrent corneal erosions with gradual visual blurring in childhood are typical of Bowman layer dystrophies.

questions.text: What is the pattern of corneal opacities seen in Theil-Behnke dystrophy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Thiel-Behn ke corneal dystrophy presents with a reticular or honeycomb pattern of subepithelial corneal opacities, most commonly in the central cornea.

  • It is also called honeycomb-shaped corneal dystrophy or corneal basement dystrophy type II (CBD2).
  • This dystrophy involves the Bowman layer, caused by mutations in the TGFB1 gene.
  • Symptoms include recurrent corneal erosions starting in childhood and gradual visual impairment.
  • On a slit-lamp exam, a network of fine rings or honeycomb-like opacities is seen.

Related Important Points:

Explanation of other options:

Fingerprint (Option B): Seen in epithelial basement membrane dystrophy (EBMD).

Dots (Option C): Seen in Cogan dystrophy, EBMD, or early granular dystrophy.

Amoebic (Option D): Refers to Acanthamoeba keratitis, not dystrophy.

Key Takeaway:

  • Thiel-Behnke dystrophy is marked by reticular (honeycomb-like) corneal opacities in the Bowman layer.

choices.text: Irregular thickening of the epithelium basement membrane
Fibro-cellular layer with a saw-tooth pattern between epithelium and stroma

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding histologic features of Bowman membrane dystrophy is/are correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bowman layer dystrophies, including Reis-Bücklers and Thiel-Behnke dystrophy, show distinctive histologic features:

  • In Thiel-Behnke dystrophy, histopathology shows irregular thickening of the epithelial basement membrane. (Option A)
  • The Bowman layer is replaced by a fibrocellular layer with a characteristic wavy saw-tooth appearance between the epithelium and stroma. (Option B)
  • In Reis-Bücklers dystrophy, the subepithelial tissue contains fibrillar or granular hyaline deposits that stain red with Masson trichrome (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

  • Bowman layer corneal dystrophies show saw-tooth fibrocellular changes, basement membrane irregularities, and Masson trichrome-positive hyaline deposits on histology.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient reports to OPD with c/o recurrent redness and watering from both eyes for the past few months. The patient has also noticed a few white spots in both his eyes. Coarse deposits are noted between the epithelium and stroma of the cornea in both eyes. What is the current treatment of choice for this patient? Clinical imaging is as depicted below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents with Bowman layer corneal dystrophy (likely Reis-Bücklers or Thiel-Behnke dystrophy), which manifests as:

  • Recurrent corneal erosions
  • Subepithelial corneal deposits
  • Visual disturbance due to superficial opacities

PTK using an excimer laser is the treatment of choice in symptomatic patients with superficial deposits. It ablates the irregular surface and removes the abnormal tissue precisely, improving vision and reducing the recurrence of erosions.

Key Takeaway:

  • Phototherapeutic keratectomy (PTK) is the preferred treatment for Bowman layer corneal dystrophies with recurrent erosions and subepithelial opacities.

questions.text: What material is deposited between the corneal lamellae in Stromal dystrophies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Stromal corneal dystrophies are a group of genetically inherited disorders where abnormal material accumulates between the lamellae of the corneal stroma, leading to progressive visual impairment.

  • In granular corneal dystrophy Type I, the deposits are primarily hyaline, which stain bright red with Masson trichrome.
  • Other dystrophies may show amyloid (e.g., lattice dystrophy) or mixed deposits, but hyaline is the hallmark of classic granular stromal dystrophy.
  • These dystrophies typically spare the periphery and are non-inflammatory and bilateral.

Related Important Points:

Explanation of other options:

Elastin (Option B): Elastin is not deposited in stromal dystrophies; it is normally present in elastic tissues such as skin and blood vessels, not in corneal stroma.

Proteins (Option C): Although all deposits are proteinaceous in nature, the specific type of abnormal protein matters, hyaline or amyloid, making "proteins" a non-specific answer.

Key Takeaway:

Hyaline is the primary material deposited between stromal lamellae in granular stromal corneal dystrophies.

choices.text: Opacification may involve the corneal centre

questions.text: Which of the following is/ are features of Stromal corneal dystrophies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Stromal corneal dystrophies are bilateral, hereditary, and non-inflammatory conditions that usually begin around puberty and progress slowly over decades.

  • Onset is typically in childhood or early puberty (especially in autosomal dominant forms). (Option A)
  • The central cornea is most commonly affected, while the peripheral cornea is usually spared. (Option B)
  • They show progressive accumulation of hyaline or amyloid deposits, leading to visual impairment by middle age. (Option C)
  • Vision may remain unaffected for years, and treatment (e.g., keratoplasty) is usually considered after significant progression.

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway:

Stromal corneal dystrophies are bilateral, slow-progressive disorders with onset around puberty and central corneal involvement.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old patient presents with a diminution of vision in BE. On SLE, opacities are seen throughout the cornea at the level of the stroma with no intervening space between them. Clinical imaging is as shown.

What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Macular corneal dystrophy is the only stromal dystrophy with autosomal recessive inheritance, and is characterised by:

  • Poorly defined grey-white stromal opacities without intervening clear areas
  • Onset in the first or second decade, with early visual deterioration
  • Opacities may extend from the anterior to the posterior stroma, including the peripheral cornea, and coalesce over time
  • Histology reveals glycosaminoglycan deposits, which stain with Alcian blue or colloidal iron
  • Unlike granular or lattice dystrophies, no clear stromal lamellae are seen between opacities

Related Important Points:

Explanation of other options:

Epithelial basement membrane dystrophy (Option A): Affects the epithelium with map-dot-fingerprint patterns, not full stromal opacities.

Lattice corneal dystrophy (Option B): Features branching refractile lattice lines with clear intervening spaces.

Fuchs's dystrophy (Option D): An endothelial dystrophy, typically seen in older adults, is not relevant to stromal opacities in a teenager.

Key Takeaway:

  • Macular corneal dystrophy presents in adolescence with diffuse stromal opacities, no intervening clear spaces, and early visual impairment.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old patient presents with a diminution of vision in BE. On SLE, opacities are seen throughout the cornea at the level of the stroma with no intervening space between them. Clinical imaging is as shown.

What is the material deposited in the cornea in this dystrophy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical description is consistent with macular corneal dystrophy, a stromal dystrophy characterised by:

  • Diffuse, ill-defined grey-white opacities in the corneal stroma with no intervening clear spaces
  • Autosomal recessive inheritance (CHST6 gene mutation)
  • Early onset and progressive visual impairment
  • Histologically, the deposits consist of glycosaminoglycans, which stain positively with Alcian blue and colloidal iron

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway:

  • Macular corneal dystrophy involves stromal deposition of glycosaminoglycans, leading to diffuse, confluent opacities.

questions.text: Which stain positivity is seen in Lattice corneal dystrophy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lattice corneal dystrophy is a stromal dystrophy characterised by deposition of amyloid material, seen as branching, refractile lattice lines in the anterior stroma.

  • Amyloid deposits stain positively with Congo red and exhibit green birefringence under polarised light.
  • This is a key histological clue that distinguishes lattice dystrophy from other stromal dystrophies.
  • Other stains are used for different corneal deposits:
    • Masson Trichrome: Hyaline (Granular dystrophy) (Option A ruled out)
    • Alcian Blue: Glycosaminoglycans (Macular dystrophy) (Option C ruled out)
    • Sudan Black: Lipids (e.g., in lipid degeneration) (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaway:

  • Lattice corneal dystrophy involves amyloid deposition, which stains with Congo red and shows green birefringence.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding endothelial corneal dystrophies is/are correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Endothelial corneal dystrophies, particularly Fuchs endothelial corneal dystrophy (FECD), are:

  • Most commonly seen in the elderly population, especially over the age of 50.
  • Show a strong female preponderance.
  • Characterised by progressive endothelial cell loss, formation of guttae, and eventual stromal oedema and blurred vision, especially in the mornings.

Other endothelial dystrophies like posterior polymorphous corneal dystrophy (PPCD) may be congenital, but Fuchs dystrophy is the most common and classically adult-onset.

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway:

  • Fuchs endothelial dystrophy, the most common endothelial dystrophy, occurs in adults, predominantly females.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the corneal epithelium
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The corneal epithelium is a non-keratinised stratified squamous epithelium, composed of basal, wing, and superficial apical cells.
  • It is capable of regeneration, with a typical turnover every 7-10 days via limbal stem cells located at the palisades of Vogt. (Options A, C ruled out)
  • The apical cells of the epithelium are equipped with microvilli and microplate, which enhance adherence of the tear film. (Option D ruled out)
  • In contrast, the Bowman membrane, located just beneath the epithelial basement membrane, is an acellular collagenous layer that does not regenerate if damaged; instead, it is replaced by scar tissue.

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway:

  • The Bowman membrane is non-regenerative, unlike the corneal epithelium, which renews continuously.

choices.text: Oxygen is mostly derived by the epithelium directly from the tear film
Glucose supply is mainly by aqueous
Thickness is greater at the centre than periphery

questions.text: All are true regarding the cornea except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The central cornea is thinner than the peripheral cornea, not thicker.

  • The average central corneal thickness (CCT) is about 540 µm, while the periphery is thicker, approximately 700 µm.
  • The corneal endothelium plays a key role in maintaining stromal dehydration through its active ionic pump mechanism. (Option A)
  • The epithelium receives oxygen directly from the tear film (Option B)
  • The glucose supply for metabolic activity is mainly from the aqueous humour, with some contribution from limbal vasculature. (Option C)

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway:

  • The central cornea is thinner than the peripheral cornea; this difference is important in IOP measurement and refractive surgery planning.
